awd_titl_txt: WOU-MMA: Maximizing Science Output of LIGO: Data Analysis and Improved Detectors
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research in relativity and relativistic astrophysics and it addresses the priority areas of NSF's "Windows on the Universe" Big Idea. This project aims at maximizing the scientific output of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory, via formulating strategies for detector improvements and the development and implementation of new data analysis algorithms. This project will contribute to the advancement of precision measurement technology, deepen understandings of general relativity, and push the frontier of experimental physics at the interface between gravitational and quantum physics.  It also supports the observation and interpretation of multi-messenger astrophysical sources.  This project will serve as a training ground for early career physicists and astrophysicists, teaching them a wide variety of research techniques. By interacting with the broader quantum metrology community, this project will benefit other precision measurement experiments outside the gravitational-wave community.  Participants of this project will also vigorously pursue a wide range of activities that reach out to the the general public.

The primary scientific objective of this program is to drive the continued improvement of LIGO sensitivity, to enable the most efficient analysis of LIGO data, and to extract fundamental physics from upcoming LIGO detections.  More specifically: (A) The proposed research program will formulate and evaluate innovative approaches to improving LIGO's sensitivity, by inventing new quantum metrology techniques for use in future detectors, and by studying strategies toward lowering thermal noise, beam-scattering noise, and toward nonlinear regression using auxiliary channels. The program will also explore new approaches toward GW detection, e.g., atom interferometry and displacement-noise-free interferometry. By collaborating with experimentalists, participants will attempt to make theoretical progress that will eventually make impacts in real experiments. (B) Numerical relativity simulations of binary black holes and binaries containing neutron stars will be used for LIGO data analysis: (i) Simulations following up on LIGO detections will be used to verify the accuracy of phenomenological waveform models, to explore parameter biases of these models, and to perform alternative parameter estimation strategies as needed; and (ii) Surrogate waveform models, which interpolate between numerical relativity waveforms to produce a waveform at requested parameters to high accuracy, will be implemented into LALSuite and be used in parameter estimation studies on future events. (C) Aspects of general relativity will be tested and demonstrated using LIGO data, including: testing the existence of non-GR structures near the horizon, and using the coherent stacking of waveforms from multiple sources to reconstruct the emission pattern of a single source.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to maximize the scientific output of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory via formulating strategies for detector improvements and the development and implementation of new data analysis algorithms. This project contributed to advancing precision measurement technology, deepened understanding of general relativity, and pushed the frontier of experimental physics at the interface between gravitational and quantum physics. It also supported the observation and interpretation of multi-messenger astrophysical sources. This project served as a training ground for early career physicists and astrophysicists, teaching them various research techniques. By interacting with the broader quantum metrology community, this project benefited other precision measurement experiments outside the gravitational-wave community.  

Intellectual Merit

The primary scientific objective of this project is to drive the continued improvement of LIGO sensitivity, to enable the most efficient analysis of LIGO data, and to extract fundamental physics from upcoming LIGO detections. This objective has been achieved in the following ways: 

(A) The project showed that quantum parametric amplification can be used to simultaneously broaden the bandwidth of a gravitational-wave detector and increase its peak sensitivity; such amplification can also be done in a way that circumvents back-action noise. This project showed that "Displacement-Noise Free Interferometry (DFI)," which utilizes the fundamental difference between how gravitational waves and local disturbances affect the signals of a gravitational-wave detector, can be used to benefit ground-based gravitational-wave detectors. Experimental strategies proposed by this project are being studied experimentally by groups worldwide.  

(B) Numerical relativity simulations of binary black holes and binaries containing neutron stars have been applied to improve LIGO data analysis. This was done through the construction of more accurate "surrogate models," which accurately produce waveforms for a continuous range of parameters based on a finite number of highly accurate numerical relativity simulations.  

(C) Strategies have been proposed and implemented to demonstrate and test predictions of general relativity in LIGO data. To confirm the existence of event horizons around the remnant black holes produced by the coalescence of binary black holes, the project modeled features of gravitational-wave echoes that could be induced by (conjectured) deviations from general relativity near such event horizons. Regarding the ringdown wave from binary black-hole coalescence, the project invented a filtering approach that can eliminate the dominant, known parts of the wave and reveal the less dominant but more subtle (hence interesting) features, including waves generated by the nonlinearity of space-time geometry.  

Broader Impacts

Participants of this project interacted with the broader quantum-metrology community by attending conferences and forming collaborations. Synergy has been created around applying quantum parametric amplification techniques, and a wide range of quantum optomechanics experiments, including gravitational-wave detectors, are now considered candidates to search for signatures of quantum gravity and dark matter.  

The project has allowed more than ten early-career physicists (graduate students and postdoctoral scholars) to be trained in gravitational physics. They not only did analytical calculations and numerical work but also collaborated closely with experimentalists and data scientists, hence receiving broader training that allowed them to make more significant impacts. 

Participants of this project vigorously pursued a wide range of activities that reach out to the general public.
